awd_titl_txt: Fostering Student Computational Thinking with Self-Regulated Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
As a result of the powerful innovation and application of computing in STEM disciplines, the STEM+C program addresses an urgent need for real-world, interdisciplinary, and computational preparation of students from the early grades through high school (preK-12). This project will advance research and development of new transdisciplinary approaches to computational STEM teaching and learning that will integrate the fields of Computational Thinking (CT) and Self-Regulated learning (SRL) into science activities in four content areas: Earth Science, Biology, Chemistry, and Physics. The project will provide professional development (PD) for high school teachers that includes instruction on CT, SRL, and on using SPIN (Science Practices Innovation Notebook). Next, teachers will collaboratively develop lessons that infuse CT & SRL, upload the lessons into SPIN, implement those lessons in their classrooms, and then collaboratively analyze student work samples captured by SPIN. 

Throughout this PD process, researchers will collect multiple forms of data by observation, surveys, SPIN documents and artifacts as part an overall research plan. The research team will employ data analytics to uncover patterns and develop a CT learning progression for grades 9-12. The project proposes implementing four phases of iterative Design Research. In the Informed Exploration phase, researchers and practitioners will work together to find opportunities to teach CT through SRL processes during STEM investigations. The Enactment Phase will involve short iterative tests of design conjectures to develop and build the electronic notebook. The Local Impact phase will engage practitioners in testing the electronic notebook in their classes while researchers document teaching implementation and student learning of CT. In the Broader Impact phase, the electronic notebook will be scaled up to local high school teachers who did not participate in the project implementation. The project will develop an empirical learning progression for grades 9-12 that will provide more sophisticated explanations of CT with developmental step across grades.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This study, Fostering Student Computational Thinking with SRL, took on important questions in this field: How do teachers prepare lessons on data practices? Could computational thinking help teachers teach students data practices? How might teachers foster self-regulated learning in students so that they can learn independently about data practices? 

This study used a partnership between teachers and researchers to learn more about how data practices, computational thinking, and SRL interact in instruction during scientific investigations and to build an electronic notebook to support student learning. High school teachers created investigations that focused on major ideas in Earth science, biology, chemistry and physics, and researchers helped teachers to integrate computational thinking and self-regulated learning into these investigations. We then built an electronic tool together to import the lessons for student use. The co-designed tool is called Science Practices Innovation Notebook (SPIN). SPIN was built to break down data practices into 5 parts: creating data, collecting data, preparing data, visualizing data and analyzing data, as well as support students to become more aware of their learning and use computational thinking. Screenshots of SPIN can be found in the images section. 

In the first part of the study, teachers and researchers worked offline to learn more about integrating computational thinking into data practices. We developed a tool, the Task Analysis Tool (TAT), to help teachers see where they use data practices and help them to integrate computational thinking into the investigations. We learned by using this tool that teachers noticed that sometimes their lessons on investigations were too teacher-centered and shifted the learning tasks to the students before they integrated computational thinking. We also found that teachers easily were able to integrate all data practices and computational thinking into all subject areas of science (biology, chemistry, Earth science, and physics). A flow diagram in the images section shows how the different data practices matched up to the computational thinking practices.

We also found that when teachers had three new things to learn (data practices, computational thinking, and SRL, it was better to present only two at a time. Before the pandemic, teachers were more concerned with data practices and computational thinking. However, during the pandemic when students were learning remotely and having a hard time motivating themselves, teachers reported the primary importance of SRL of the three new topics in the professional development partnership. Over three years, the teachers demonstrated they learned the key concepts in all three topics. 

In the second part of the study, teachers and researchers worked together to build this supportive electronic notebook that included a communication hub and an “I’m stuck” button. Most importantly the structure of the notebook included 5 tabs at the top devoted to each of the data practices so that students could explicitly see what to do during that data practice. In studying teachers’ view of using SPIN in the classroom, we saw that because teachers designed SPIN, it fit well with classroom needs. However, the teachers found that students needed to use SPIN at least once before they focused on the science learning because they were learning the navigation and functions of SPIN instead. Teachers liked how the tool split up the 5 data practices so that they could instruct students in each practice clearly. 

The final part of the study was to use SPIN in classrooms and see if teachers who taught the same investigations using SPIN and not using SPIN had the same or different experiences with students. We found that from the teachers’ perspectives, explicitly teaching data practices (with SPIN) was more effective for students than teaching data practices implicitly (without SPIN). We also found that if teachers did not spend time helping students understand the scientific phenomenon before collecting data, that students had a difficult time understanding how to analyze the data.

In summary, this study found that breaking down tasks into smaller pieces helped both teachers and students. Teachers were able to discuss, analyze, and integrate new features into their lesson plans more effectively when breaking the investigation down with the Task Analysis Tool. Students were able to more effectively understand data practices when SPIN’s tabs broke down each data practice clearly. In terms of data practices, we found that collecting and visualizing data tends to be the easiest for students to learn, while students have some struggle with creating, preparing, and analyzing data, particularly when they do not understand the variables in the phenomenon before they begin data practices. 

The findings of this study have been disseminated in the research community and in teacher practitioner journals. The products of this research have won two awards: Programs that Work given by the Virginia Science and Mathematics Coalition and Research Worth Reading given jointly by the National Science Teaching Association and the National Association of Research in Science Teaching.
